subject: Re: Running Multiple Fixtures in junit.swingui.TestRunner
msgSnippet: ... AH.  As J.B. already said.. you could have asked for clarification. ... I may be dating myself but I still put more more faith in peer-reviewed
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jim Dixon <jdd@d...> wrote:
> On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Dave Astels wrote:
> > Of what relavance is this?
>
> JB cited what appeared to be a quotation backing his interpretation
> of the term. He appeared to be claiming that it came from the JUnit
> Web site. I was investigating the claim.

AH. As J.B. already said.. you could have asked for clarification.


> > Page 74-78, "Test-Driven Development: A Practical Guide".
>
> Hmmmm. Doesn't appear to be the JUnit Web site ...

I may be dating myself but I still put more more faith in
peer-reviewed published-by-reputable-publishers books that anything on
the web.

> Each new fixture ** is created in an instance of that subclass, used
> once, then discarded." **

> Hoist with your own petard, I would say ;-)

Why? If we wish to discuss terminology.. then.. exactly what the
*&^%#%@% does that mean? Very rude images come to mind.

> > > then recall that an object is an INSTANCE of a class.
> >
> > Well... not always... in the common-place OO languages, sure. But
> > sometimes it's a copy of a prototype.
>
> My friend

There you go making assumptions again :)

> this is the JUnit list. We are talking about Java classes.

Ah.. but you didn't say "**In Java** an object is an instance of a class"

> You may disparage Java as a commonplace OO language. That's your
> right.

Actually, it just really sucks as programming languages go... but so
do most of the currently mainstream ones.

> In Java

Java is not the whole enchilada, my friend.

> a class is a very well-specified thing, and it not the same
> thing as a instance.

Unfortunately true.\

> You really ought to know this.

Oh.. I really do. But I try not to constrain my thinking by the
limitations of a single language.

> I think that that we could use our time more productively than this.

Discussion = unproductive? Not in my world. Discussion->learning.

> I have been trying to decide whether unit testing is really
> applicable in multi-threaded applications, for example, and
> wondering how JUnit could be extended to be useful in this area.

You can;t conslusively test for correctness in a concurrent system..
at least I ready that somewhere not too long ago.. but it might have
been online.

Dave
